Award.AwardTitle: Polarization induced transport in all-polymer field-effect transistors

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this program is an integrated research and educational effort in the area of polarization induced transport in all-polymer field-effect transistors (FETs). The goals of the research are to elucidate the role of long-range polaronic interaction in ferroelectric-based FETs, to study plasmonic effects on transport by combining light scattering and transient photocurrent spectroscopy, and the development of experimental methodologies for strain mapping in pressure sensing devices.

The intellectual merit is in the development of a universal model for temperature-dependent FET mobility incorporating the effect of Fr√∂hlich polarons. The research activities involve development of polymer FETs with solution processable polar and non-polar polymer dielectrics along with a new series of push-pull-type donor-acceptor polymers. Combining surface-enhanced Raman scattering with photocurrent spectroscopy will provide a diagnostic tool to visualize transport using surface plasmons. The development of flexible pressure sensing devices based on organic FETs in conjunction with ferroelectric dielectrics is likely to have a transformative impact on technology via the feasibility of tactile electronic surfaces.

The broader impacts are on the science and technology of pressure sensing devices and multi-discipline education and outreach. The participation of high school students in a new summer program - Fielding Science - with projects on inkjet printing techniques to be further developed by undergraduate students in an Advanced Laboratory course, will advance the area of flexible electronic surfaces. Public lectures on flexible electronics will be delivered by the PI and graduate students participating in the program as part of an existing Saturday Morning Science series.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: One of the main goals of the project was to establish a platform for elucidating the nature of polarization fluctuation in the transport mechanism of organic field-effect transistors (FET). Ferroelectric dielectrics, where the dielectric constant may be tuned by an order of magnitude with temperature, are ideal for extracting information on polaron hopping lengths and barrier heights. By devising single and stacked pentacene FETs using a ferroelectric dielectric, for the first time we evaluate the nature of Fröhlich polarons in pentacene FETs. We have further gained insight into the nature of trap states in organic semiconductors and their role in interfacial transport in FETs, especially when ferroelectric dielectrics are used. Remarkably, a small molecule semiconductor (TIPS-pentacene) based FET with a ferroelectric dielectric exhibits a negative coefficient of mobility (bandlike transport, reminiscent of a metal, instead of the usual activated transport). The key to this behavior is the discrete nature of the trapping levels in TIPS-pentacene, and presumably other solution-processable pi-conjugated conductors. This NSF award has enabled us to establish a set of experimental tools exploiting light scattering and transient photocurrent spectroscopy to answer key questions pertaining to the nature of vibronic coupling as well as structural changes associated with transport in organic FETs.

We have expanded our research areas in non-linear optics to understand structure-property relationship in ferroelectric polymers and other self-assembled biopolymers.

Broader Impact: An emphasis area in printed electronics for undergraduate and high school students has been established. An undergraduate student was instrumental in initiating the printed electronics project where she was successful in printing active layers for organic solar cells and transistors. In all, four PhD students and three undergraduate students have been involved with the project. The PI and graduate students have been involved in outreach activities providing several opportunities for high school students to tour the research facilities as well as involving them in mini workshops related to organic electronics. The PI gave several public lectures on “Plastic solar cells and electronics”.


Last Modified: 06/23/2017
Modified by: Suchismita Guha

Image
  • Using a ferroelectric dielectric layer in an organic FET allows tuning of polarization strength with temperature. Remarkably, at 200 K TIPS-pentacene FETs with a ferroelectric dielectric exhibit a negative coefficient of mobility (band-like transport, instead of the usual activated transport).
    S. Guha
    Copyrighted
    Suchismita Guha
    FET transport and bulk transport in TIPS-pentacene.
